title: Pedialyte vs Gatorade: What's the Difference?

steps.title: Gatorade is intended for adult athletes, while Pedialyte targets all ages.
steps.content: Gatorade is intended for adult athletes, while Pedialyte targets all ages. Pedialyte is an oral rehydration solution (ORS) formulated to optimize fluid absorption, especially in children and older adults. [1] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Gatorade, on the other hand, is marketed as a sports drink; it boosts athletic performance by restoring electrolytes and blood sugar lost during a workout (due to sweating). [2] X Research source Pedialyte and Gatorade are more hydrating than water because they include electrolytes that prevent and treat dehydration . [3] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Pedialyte offers more electrolytes than Gatorade.
steps.content: Pedialyte offers more electrolytes than Gatorade. Electrolytes are minerals that support bodily functions like fluid regulation, muscle function, and pH balance; you lose electrolytes when you sweat, so it’s important to replace them quickly to prevent dehydration. [4] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source Compared to Gatorade, Pedialyte contains significantly greater sodium, potassium, chloride, and zinc (electrolytes). [5] X Research source Rehydrate immediately if you notice any of the following sign of dehydration: fatigue, dizziness, confusion, extreme thirst, dark-colored urine, less frequent urination [6] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Pedialyte has significantly less sugar than Gatorade.
steps.content: Pedialyte has significantly less sugar than Gatorade. Gatorade contains a high amount of sugar to increase fuel mid-workout. One 12-ounce (0.35L) serving of Gatorade’s Thirst Quencher contains 21 grams (0.74 oz) of sugar, while one 12-ounce (0.35L) serving of Pedialyte Classic has approximately 9 grams (0.32 oz) of sugar. [7] X Research source [8] X Research source The American Heart Association recommends a daily sugar intake of 24 grams (0.85 oz) for women and 36 grams (1.3 oz) for men, so avoid drinking Gatorade regularly: one bottle of Gatorade’s Thirst Quencher has 48 grams (1.7 oz) of sugar. [9] X Research source [10] X Research source

steps.title: Select Pedialyte if you're sick.
steps.content: Select Pedialyte if you're sick. Pedialyte replaces fluids lost through vomiting or diarrhea, and it’s a better option than Gatorade because it contains less sugar. Sugar makes stomach flu symptoms worse because it pulls excess water into the gut, disrupting the gastrointestinal tract. [11] X Research source To cope with a stomach flu , make sure to drink enough fluids and eat bland foods (bananas, rice, apples, toast). One 12-ounce (0.35L) serving of Pedialyte Classic provides 25% of the Daily Value (DV) of zinc, which increases water absorption and reduces diarrhea. [12] X Research source [13] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Go with Gatorade for sports recovery.
steps.content: Go with Gatorade for sports recovery. For athletes, Gatorade contains a high level of sugar to increase endurance and energy. For non-athletes, it’s just another sugary drink; only choose Gatorade to replenish electrolytes during high-intensity exercise. [14] X Research source As a general rule, drink Gatorade one hour into your workout; if you’re outside (or a heavy sweater), you may want to reach for it every 30-45 minutes instead. [15] X Research source For a sugar-free alternative, choose Gatorade Zero.

steps.title: Choose Pedialyte to relieve hangover symptoms.
steps.content: Choose Pedialyte to relieve hangover symptoms. Alcohol has a diuretic effect that makes you pee more than usual, promoting water loss and dehydration. [16] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Although electrolyte drinks aren’t scientifically-proven hangover cures , they can reduce common symptoms like headaches and nausea. Pedialyte is a better option than Gatorade because it carries twice the amount of electrolytes to fight dehydration and feel better faster. [17] X Research source If you don’t have Pedialyte and want to avoid excess sugar, drink coconut water instead. It’s full of electrolytes and low in calories and sugar, making it a perfect natural alternative. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Generally, Pedialyte is a better option than Gatorade.
steps.content: Generally, Pedialyte is a better option than Gatorade. Pedialyte and Gatorade are both electrolyte-packed rehydration drinks, but they serve different purposes. Pedialyte is an excellent option to treat illness and hangovers, while Gatorade is only the preferred option when it comes to exercise. Unless you’re performing a high-intensity workout, Pedialyte is your best option–it’s packed with more electrolytes to rehydrate your body quickly. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Long-term consumption of Pedialyte or Gatorade isn't considered healthy.
steps.content: Long-term consumption of Pedialyte or Gatorade isn't considered healthy. Remember that Pedialyte and Gatorade are not “health drinks”: don’t replace all your water with either beverage, and check with your doctor first to see if daily use is recommended. If you’re simply thirsty, plain water is the best choice. [20] X Research source While Pedialyte has less sugar and calories than Gatorade, it contains a substantial amount of sodium–370 mg per serving, or 16% of the Daily Value (DV). [21] X Research source Avoid drinking Pedialyte if you have hypertension (high blood pressure) or kidney problems. [22] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source
